text:
Hi guys I"m Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I'm going to show
you a re ally easy treat.

This is a scotcharoo - the way I like to think
of a scotcharoo is kind of like a hybrid between

a buckeye which is a delicious little rice
cereal peanut butter chocolate ball, and a
butterscotch rice crispy treat.
Mix them to combine, and that's what you get.

And they are so good, absolutely addictive,
when you make these get them out of your house

as soon as humanly possible because you will
consume the entire 9 by 13 pan, I should know
because I have tried.

Let me run you through the ingredients, the
list is short and sweet, kind of like me,
you need some rice cereal to start.

I have this in a big pot because you need
a lot of surface to toss it.
I also have some creamy smooth peanut butter.

You need some granulated sugar, this is some
light corn syrup, you can use honey if you
want to.

I've got some vanilla extract and you're also
going to need some dark chocolate chips and

some butterscotch chocolate chips which I
have in the back because there's not a ton
of room here.

Alright, so let's get started and like I said
if you don't want to use light corn syrup

you can use honey if you want to, the only
difference is that honey is going to give

you a bit of a floraly after taste, delicious,
but I really want the pure peanut butter chocolate

and butterscotch to come through and I don't
want anything to disturb that so that's why
I'm using light corn syrup.

So, in the saucepan I'm going to add the sugar
and the corn syrup, and keep in mind that

this is by no means something that you should
make often, it's a total treat once in a blue

moon you can make this but like I said it's
a very sweet, very indulgent, and it uses

ingredients that I don't usually use on a
normal basis, so worth the splurge!

I'm going to bring this to a simmer, just
want to cook it long enough for the sugar

to dissolve and then I'll show you the next
step.

Once you bring it to a simmer and it comes
up to a boil, you don't want to boil this

for a long time you just want to turn this
off because the sugar is just about dissolved

at this point, you turn that baby off, and
you're going to add your peanut butter.

Let me switch to a spatula because it's a
little bit easier to get the peanut butter

out, now this is not the time to use the all
natural peanut butter because it will split

and it will be a disaster, so just add smooth
peanut butter right in carefully because you

do have boiling sugar and you want to make
sure that you don't splash it on yourself

so add that right in along with a splash of
good quality vanilla extract and now all you're

going to do is stir this together until the
peanut butter kind of is melted and it's harmonious

and it's smooth and wonderful in that corn
syrup mixture, and as you can see it's happening

it doesn't take very long at all, you just
need to be patient and just stir.

Then just pour this, make sure you're using
a heat proof spatula if you are going to use
a spatula.
Pour that right in - ah smells so good!

And then you just mix, you want to - this
is why I like to use a big pot - because I

like to make sure that I mix it really well
and if I'm using a bowl and it's not big enough,
then everything goes everywhere.

Alright, once you have everything pretty thoroughly
mixed, you're going to just dump the whole

shabang into a 9 by 13 inch baking dish that
you've lined with parchment paper and you've
sprayed with non-stick spray.

You can use coconut oil if you want to, this
just helps things not stick - got it out!

Alright and now what I'm doing now is I'm
just using my spatula, and I'm just kind of

moving things around to make sure everything's
even then just kind of pushing down on everything

to compact this a little bit and then what
I'm going to do next is I'm going to just

mix together the chocolate chips, the bittersweet
chocolate and the buttersweet - my goodness

can I just get a sentence out without complicating
things?

- Butterscotch chips and the other chocolate
chips - melt them together, badda bing meet
me back here to smear it.
There you go!

Alright, my chocolate chips are almost melted,
at the very last second I just kind of like

to mix it all in myself and just melt the
rest of those chips just with the residual

heat just so I know I'm not burning my chocolate,
now I'm using bittersweet chocolate and butterscotch

chips because the butterscotch obviously is
traditional in a scotcharoo - but most people

like to use a milk chocolate or a semi-sweet
but I think there's so much sweetness going

on that you need a little bit of dark chocolate
just to kind of offset that and that's why
I like to use dark chocolate and the butterscotch.

And then you just pour this gorgeous rather
beautiful shiny lava like mixture on top and
then just smooth it out.

Just get it nice and smooth from one corner
to the other, kind of get it in as even as

you can get it because it's kind of important,
and now it's important that you just kind

of let this cool and set before you cut into
them, so I'm just going to set them aside

until I'm ready for them which will be in
a couple of hours and then we will cut and
serve!

Alright, my scotcharoos have set now for a
couple of hours, don't mind me that I can't

cut straight, it's just the story of my life
but it doesn't really matter because these
smell so good and they're so mmm!

That butterscotch smell with the chocolate,
I love life!
Mmm!

There's no words, not too sweet, perfect,
perfect balance of peanut butter to butterscotch,

slightly crumbly not too too dense, but absolutely
perfection!
Ugh!

Why do I keep looking at it like it's going
to do something magnificent?

Go to LauraintheKitchen.com to get the written
recipe, I hope you have enjoyed spending time
with me I'll give you the bite, come on!
I'll see you next time, bye!
